description.text: I ran out of screws and nuts and could not wait to mount the bearings 608Z in my just printed RostockMax Spool holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:106977) You will need to print 4 sets. There are two versions for the screw, with and without shoulder (the last is faster to print). Of course, you can use this set for other stuff :-) Enjoy! BTW, thanks for the design Tom (daftscience http://www.thingiverse.com/daftscience/overview). PS. I had only to wait 1 hour designing and 80 mins printing + 30 mins troubleshooting, vs 30 mins travel to my local shop. But the fun is timeless :-)
Just print an entire set to fasten a 608Z bearing. I printed it at 0.17mm layer, 45mm/s, white PLA.

This is a simple toy boat with some detail, but not very much. I am printing one for my 7 month old son, well actually it is for his room. Made in SolidWorks.

If you print this one without scaling, it would be about 10 inches long so you may want to scale it down before printing. I will upload a picture of the printed model when I have it done.
I made a 1/4 scale print on a uPrint. I left the bottom of the boat in the xy plane and printed with a layer thickness of 0.010 inches, with a low density infill. I have some banding on the deck of the boat, but the model printed in about 25 minutes with no problems. 
*This is an iPhone picture, maybe I can get a better picture up later. :)

description.text: Vulcan mysticism tells us there is Infinite Diversity in Infinite Combinations in the universe. The Kol-Ut-Shan, represented as a pendant here, symbolizes this philosophy. We could all use a reminder that diversity is good. Logic dictates that you should print this for yourself, your friends and family, and wear it with nerdy pride.

• Print.
  • Color circle with a Sharpie. This adds to the authentic cheesyness.
  • Add bling to the little circle. I prefer a self-adhesive backed gem in the traditional clear, but don't let Vulcan tradition stifle your human creativity.
  • Attach a ribbon or string to the pendant. I like 1.2mm elastic cord which just fits through the holes.
  • Wear with nerdy pride, and support diversity in the workplace, neighborhood, friend circles, family, and world.

title: It's Miku!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: ã¯ã˜ã‚ã¾ã—ã¦ã€åˆéŸ³ãƒŸã‚¯ã§ã™! A 3D scan of a Miku figurine I own, made with a NextEngine scanner in ScanStudio HD PRO. This was my first run at 3d scanning something, so the mesh has a few problems (holes). I was also unable to get the figure to stay in one pose long enough to get multiple angles. Update! Successfully made on an Up! printer using 0.2mm layers. The body seems to be 2 discrete closed forms, however, so some gluing was involved. Hopefully I'll get a better scan later.

The scanner was not able to capture the joint area between her outsize pigtails and her head, so they are actually separate entities. Full support is needed if you want to try printing it.
Some parts of it seem to have errors which cause ReplicatorG to generate garbage. The software that comes with the Up! printer seems to handle it fine, as does CatalystEX.

title: Chess Set for my Dad
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a chess set that I designed for my dad for his birthday this year.
My dad taught me how to make, create, design, build, program, and solder from a young age.  This year I finally remembered that parents don't like their children to buy them expensive things, they like their children to build them things.  And you could end up making the worst looking thing ever, but they'll love it, just because you made it. 
Happy birthday dad.

Using two of your favorite colours, cut out two sets of chess pieces and grid squares.  Depending on your cut quality, the chess pieces may press-fit together (though hopefully not too tight, or they may crack), or you may have to use a little acrylic glue to seal them together.
Place the grid pieces on a 12x12 inch ~4.5mm sheet of acrylic in an 8x8 grid for the chess board itself.  Because the acrylic glue can leave bubbles between pieces, I just left these unglued and loose.  I like this a lot more, and makes it look a lot more haphazard and visually interesting.

comments.text: Hi, I looked for colored acrylic sheets like the one you have but I cant find any. Any idea where I can get some? Can I order it online?
comments.author: Nidhi

comments.text: Acrylic sheet is very common, and most plastics supply stores should stock 1/8 acrylic in various colours.  If you don't have one locally, there are many places to order acrylic sheet online, from Inventables (though it's usually a little pricey) to even Amazon.  Best of luck!

Do you have a simple solution to adapt your design to laser cut a 20" x 20 " board ? (still with 4.5mm sheets).

comments.author: PoussPouss

comments.text:
Hi Cam,
I think you'd just have to scale the board squares by 167%. If you'd also like to cut larger pieces, you'll need to scale them too. If you go that route, you may just want to scale them until the press-fit gap becomes the thickness of the plastic that you'd like to use, and try a few test pieces to see how the size/fit works.

comments.author: peter_

comments.text: Sorry if it was unclear, but the board is the only 4.5mm piece.  I think the chess pieces are 1/8? (~3mm?).  Check the design files, and just scale it to whatever gap is appropriate, and cut out a test piece to see if it looks good, or if you'll need to scale the piece outlines and the slots separately.

I took the rotary plate from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:161378
(Rotary plate for 3D Scanner by VattaFarI) and resized it to 130% which is the 195mm size that works for the 3D Scanner based off FabScan open source project by Ceb (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:284142). So far this one works with the 3mm screws on each size of the motor under it for the turntable. Please see my comments under Ceb's project if you are building this. This was my third turntable and it works great. Now I just need to fine tune the software!

Here are the 92 Duals of the Johnson Polyhedra, see thing:16508. They were constructed by the method described in thing:30958, Duals of Polyhedra. You can read about duals on Wikipedia or on the dual page at George Hart's Virtual Polyhedra Site, see http://www.georgehart.com/virtual-polyhedra/duality.html Simply put if object A is transformed to object B by some process and if B is tranformed back to A by the same process, A and B are duals. In this case A and B are different but related polyhedra. The vertices of A become the faces of B and vice versa. Ninety-two are too many polyhedra to show here though all are printable. It seemed better to present a few examples of the orginal Johnson polyhedra together with their duals to show how the process works. Compounds of the duals and their polyhedra are included as they are helpful in understanding the relationships. In the compounds the vertices of the original polyhedron protrude from the faces of the dual. Stl files are: Example 1: J9.stl, J9_dual.stl and compound_j9.stl Example 2: J12.stl, J12_dual.stl and compound_j12.stl Example 3: J16.stl, J16_dual.stl and compound_j16.stl The fortran program that produced the openSCAD programs and the openSCAD programs that generated the duals are included in johnson_duals_scad.zip. The stl files of all the duals are included in johnson_duals_stl.zip

Four of the stl files need to be printed with external support. They are:
compound_j9.stl, J12.stl, compound_j12.stl, and compound_j16.stl. Example 1. J9.stl is the Johnson polyhedron. It is an elongated pentagonal pyramid with 5 square faces, 5 triangular faces and a single pentagonal face. Its dual, J9_dual.stl,. is similar but only the pentagonal face is regular. Both polyhedra have 11 vertices. Vertices of J9 protrude from the dual in the compound. Example 2. J12 is a triangular dipyramid composed of 6 equilateral triangles. It has only 5 vertices. Its dual is a triangular prism composed of two triangles and 3 rectangles with 6 vertices. The 5 vertices of J12 protrude from the dual in the compound. Example 3. J16 is a elongated pentagonal dipyramid with 5 square and ten triangular faces. It has 12 vertices. J16_dual is an elongated pentagonal prism. It has two regular pentagonal faces joined by 10 identical trapezoids and has 15 vertices. The 12 vertices of J16 protrude from the dual in the compound.

A box made from cuts from a 2D laser printer, then glued together.

In order to make the box, I simply cut out the pattern generated from http://boxmaker.rahulbotics.com/ and rastered it using 600 DPI, with 50 speed, 100 power, with vector cutting at 40 speed, 100 power, and 500 frequency. This is however, not recommended, for it will take about an hour to raster and cut everything. Therefore, it is recommended to change the DPI to a lower setting and adjust the settings. Once finished, simply glue together using wood glue.

We ended up using a clear power supply which had a fan on the bottom of it's case.  We drilled a hole into the bottom of makerbot 1280 to allow the fan to function, and decided to make some feet to futher support the makerbot and allow more air to reach the fan.  A nice side effect of this is that the blue leds that are in the fan shine out the bottom of the device, giving it a nice unearthly glow.

This is a very easy part to make.  The hole in the center is designed and tested to use the extra screws included with the makerbot kit.
Pictures can be found in the flickr Makerbot pool.  Look for Edagawa.
I've added the Sketchup source file, although it would probably be easier to model a new one than to modify this file - it's that easy!

"Every empire crumbles beneath the wheels of time." --Qie Zi, The Art of Seej This is a plaster-cast Sidewalk Chalk Bloxen, sculpted with a chisel and scanned with Autodesk 123D Catch. It's a fully usable Seej bloxen: I edited the scanned mesh to include a pair of mortises on the bottom.

No assembly necessary. Just print and play Seej. You can grab the STLs for the original molds on Thingiverse. --=] Copypasta Seej Verbiage [=-- Seej is a tabletop wargame based around 3D printing. Check out http://s33j.net for rules and more information. If you're not playing Seej yet, you'll need the Seej starter set: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24013

description.text: Remake of the classic embroidery ring with tension screw

Simply print the 3 parts. In order to assemble it you'll need two M4 hex nuts and a M4 bolt of 50mm.
Insert the bolt into the the 'adjustment screw' part and add one of the M4 nuts and tighten this. Add a little 'Loctite'to prevent the nut from loosening itself.
Insert the other M4 hex nut in the outer ring and secure it in place with a drop superglue and let it dry for a couple of minutes and you're ready to go!!

This "thing" generates bridged eyecaps for binoculars. Unfortunately, nowadays most binoculars no longer come with decent eyecaps which are connected by a flexible bridge and stay attached to the binocular strap. Instead, new binoculars are often only delivered with two simple plastic caps which get lost very quickly. Module eyecaps() in the included SCAD file is fully parametrized. The main parameters of the module are used to configure:
  • outer diameter of the eyepieces
  • distance between the eyepieces when fully opened
  • size and number of strap loops
  • number and type of bridge between the eyecaps
    • The example STL files are parametrized for the following binoculars:
  • Minolta 7x21 (31mm eyepiece)
  • Nikon Sportstar EX 8x25 (33mm eyepiece)
  • Pentax DCF 9x28 (35mm eyepiece)
    • For other eyepiece diameters, distances and bridge configurations just modify the SCAD file by adding your own call to module eyecaps() at the end of the file. Given that the eyecaps bridges need to be flexible when the binoculars are folded for storage, the material of choice for printing the eyecaps is definitely ABS.

Buy all the parts, then print the parts here: (total cost is around Â£200, total weight around 1.4kg) From HobbyKing:

Total: Â£193 including delivery From ebay: carbon fibre tubes http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/150766369446 Â£11
XT60 power connectors http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/120983871463 Â£4 I don't know if anyone will actually build this, but this is vaguely what to do: The motors screw into the holders with m3 screws from below. The wires thread through the tubes. The holes for the carbon fibre tubes print slightly undersized on purpose - I don't glue them, they're just a friction fit. I rolled up some sandpaper, and enlarged the hole gradually until the rod just barely went in (considerable force.) Every time I crash the quad, they rotate slightly, which I consider better than trying to glue them and have something actually break. Use m4 bolts to screw the base and top to the central rod holders. They should self-tap. The ESCS fit inside the case, I had to bodge the wiring to get it to fit. I'll eventually design a top cover, but for now the flight control board and RX just sit on top, secured by bolts/cable ties respectively. I tapped the holes to m3 size, but they'd probably self-thread. If anyone has any questions/comments just ask, I know when I built this it was really hard to find a working configuration of motors/escs/batteries/etc. This set works really nicely. I've had a few crashes from 5m, going fast over the ground, and the whole thing has just bounced, and i've only broken one prop so far.

title: Henry Bowen Anthony Fountain - Female Face 1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Detail scan of a female face from the Henry Bowen Anthony fountain in Lippit Park at the head of Blackstone Boulevard in Providence RI. The fountain was installed in 1940 to honor Rhode Island U.S. Senator Henry Bowen Anthony, who served as a U.S. senator (1859 to 1884), Rhode Island governor (1849-1851), and publisher of The Providence Journal. Designed in a modern style by the Providence firm Jackson, Robertson & Adams, the fountain is the centerpiece of Lippitt Park, where Hope Street meets Blackstone Boulevard, near the Pawtucket city line It was scanned with 123D Catch and the raw scan is available here: http://www.123dapp.com/obj-Catch/Henry-Bowen-Anthony-Fountain--Female-Stone-Face--1/874819 This scan is featured in the "Scanning in 3D" chapter of Getting Started with MakerBot : shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920026723.do? Also appearing in Make: Ultimate Guide to 3D Printing: http://www.makershed.com/Make_Ultimate_Guide_to_3D_Printing_p/1449357377.htm

I recommend printing the first file listed: "femaleStoneFace1_Base.stl". It is already rotated with the flat side down.   It prints well  on my Replicator in yellow Ultimachine PLA at 0.25mm layer height with the default acceleration settings.   Extruder temp 220 degrees, HBP 50 degrees.
The scan without the base is included, and is imported by the OpenSCAD file.  If you want to modify the OpenSCAD, make sure the "femaleStoneFace1.stl" is in the same directory.  If printing the scan without the base, rotate the model so the flat side is facing down on the platform.

title: Thing-o-matic LED Replacement for Heater Board

description.text: The heaterboard was not heating up, so we installed a new LED and the board now works properly.

Problem: heater board was not heating
  • Test the heater board to make sure it was not working; it did not heat up and the LED did not turn on.
  • Remove the heater board from the Thing-o-matic (TOM).
  • There are 5 components that would affect the boardâ€™s ability to heat up â€“ three resistors, LED, and capacitor. Check the three resistors first as they are the easiest components to measure. The LED is more likely to not work than the capacitor, so we decided to change the LED first.
  • To change the LED, heat the soldering iron and then apply it to the metal to heat it up, to remove the LED.
  • When we removed the LED, we used pliers to pick it off, but it ended up breaking the used LED. (A possible suggestion would be to heat the solder for longer and remove one side, then heat the other side and pull it off with the pliers.) This caused some of the metal connecting the LED and motor to be messed up, therefore we also had to come up with a way to have a connection from the motor to the LED.
  • Solder in place the new LED.

An easy to remove and attach extruder for the Reprap. Press the levers and remove the motor part so you can remove the filament from the heater element.  I also included a rudimentary exploded view.

The black flexing parts are cut from 3mm Delrin. The isolator has edges on the bottom and top so it can be centered and clamped between the ring and mounting plate.
More instructions are included in the EPS file.

description.text: Fabricate your own red bird from the famous game.  This creature is made with a 3D printer and a laser cutter, along with some acrylic paint.

• 3D print (red ABS) the redbirdbody.stl file (it is a small rhombicosidodecahedron, for you polyhedron enthusiasts), scale to approx. 3 inches in x, y, and z. If you don't have red ABS, you can print in white and paint with acrylic or spray paint for plastic.

  • 3D print (yellow ABS) the 2 beak files. Scale to approx (0.7 inches x, 0.8 inches y, 0.67 inches z) for the lower beak, and scale to (0.7 inches x, 0.8 inches y, 1.33 inches z) for the upper beak.

  • Paint the belly area with either white acrylic paint, or white spray paint for plastic. I painted a pentagon surrounded by one row of squares and rectangles, which formed a decagon-shaped belly. (See photo of painted belly).

  • Laser cut the feather tuft, tail, and eye pieces. I used 1/8" acrylic in black, white, and red.

  • Join the beak pieces and laser cut pieces to the bird body. I use Tenax-7R plastic welder with good results.

  • If desired, coat the non-painted ABS areas with a thin layer of acetone to give it a shiny finish.

title: Cooling ducts for rostock max - 25mm fan

description.text:
I couldn't find a cooling duct for the rostock max that I believed was light weight enough and provided enough air flow. so i made my own.
instructions for printing and mounting in instructions tab.
I have provided 2 variants of the ducts. The first fits the standard rostock platform that comes with the rostock from seemecnc. The second version has a longer stem. This is because I have recently upgraded to magnetic ball joints and the new platform interferes with the mounting alignment so I have extended the stem and ducting.
uses 3x 25mm fans and whatever mounting screws you have lying around.
Happy Printing :)
-Cambrian Grenier
CGD.inc

PRINTING.
I found the best orientation for printing is to rotate it on the x axis by 30 degrees so it is setting on the back flat section.
That way you can print without support.
For simplicity i have included 1 .stl for each variant of 3 ducts in the correct orientation.
MOUNTING:
To mount the ducts i used 3 extra bolts and nuts that came with the printer and to mount the 25mm fans i used 4 small wood screws that fit through the fan.
Mount them between the arms using the extra holes that would be for the hot-end aluminum supports. Its all rather straight forward once you are looking at it :P
Happy Printing!
  • Cambrian Grenier
    CGD.inc

title: Star Citizen TIB and REDACTED Stamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Star Citizen is a Space Sim game being developed by Chris Roberts, CIG, RSI.  
With the huge amount of forum traffic, videos, and events dealing with the upcoming game, T.I.B. and REDACTED have become very popular catchphrases within the community. Not quite Leeroy Jenkins yet, but you never know.  
This project started with attempts to make stamps of the Imperium Division Logos, but when small enough for the ink pad  they did not ink-stamp as well as I would have liked. (TIB results).  
So I redacted the logo effort and shifted focus to these instead. They came out very usable once sized correctly.  
Hope you enjoy them. Happy Printing. - DRUM out

These are thick enough that a 20% fill is adequate.
Used ABS, so Acetone secured the handle very well. There is a flexible plastic available now. I have not worked with it yet, but with it being less rigid the results may be better when used as a stamp. If you try some and it works well for stamps, please leave a comment. Once the ink pad was generously saturated, these gave acceptable results at 2 inches (50mm) and 3 inches (80mm). Larger is always better with stamps.
Note that if you expand the stamp size the Handle.STL will also need modifying. - DRUM out

comments.text:
Kind of curious that more stamps are downloaded than Handles. It wasn't noted in the instructions, but you need the Handle to keep your fingers out of the Ink.
Just sayin... - DRUM out

author: Brokendrum

description.text:
A new version of the knurled finishing library with some added refinements, information, new modules and features.
(Everything detailed in the Instructions section)
Did my best to keep this backwards compatible with the previous knurl library.
Unfortunatelly, this thing keeps on finding it hard to render (as from example 06 you'll need to compile to see the output).
Hope you enjoy it.

Refinements: Changed the way the final shape of the knurled cylinder is made.
Information: Console ECHO for the knurled cylinder final diameters (top and bottom of the knurl)
More Info: Added the module "knurl_help()" that echoes available modules and parameters.
New module: "knurl()" parameters supported but not required, will generate a knurled cylinder with some "default" parameters.
Updated "Ends Smoothing" functionality: In the previous version this was "carving a bevel" to the knurled cylinder, now it can also "emboss that bevel". This can be of some use when substracting the cylinder from another cylinder.
Set "e_smooth" parameter to a positive value to carve, set it to a negative value to emboss, set it to zero for no bevel at all. The value is for the height of the bevel.
Browse the examples in the OpenSCAD and play a little bit with them!
Please do check the PDF available in thing:9095 if you need more information.

comments.text: OpenScad is depreciating the assign module... this is the error that appears
comments.author: theroar

comments.text:
Yes, you're right, OpenSCAD doesn't support variables, in the past, the "assign" trick was the only way to "assign" different values to a constant. Now you can do a direct assignment just using the equal sign.
I don't use the assign module any more in my new OpenSCAD scripts which often call (use/include) my old libraries with assigns without any problem but the warning message in the console.
I can live with that.
One day it will not work any more and I will have to do something about it unless someone else takes the time to post a derivative without those assigns ;)
Thanks for the comment!

I did this by rotating a long cube 45 degrees and making a bunch of them in a for loop, then do it again at -45 degrees.
Probably a better way to do this (I am new at OpenSCAD) but here is what I have:
module cross_hatching() {
intersection() {
for(i = [1:110]) {
translate([1.5i,-L/4,0])rotate([45,90,0])rotate([0,0,45])cube([1,1,5W], center=true);
translate([1.5i,L/4,0])rotate([-45,90,0])rotate([0,0,45])cube([1,1,5W], center=true);
}
translate([L/2,0,0])cube([0.9L,0.9W, 10], center = true);
}
}

title: Rowing shell boat navigation light
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A navigation light for your single, double, or 4, or 8 so that you can be seen during early morning practices.
Easy to build for $20, similar to lights that cost $60.
This looks like it should be bright enough, but it would also be possible to design one with two lights on each side.  Please leave me feedback!

Requires:
  • two "Life Gear" brand glow sticks - one red (port), one green (starboard).
  • 4 copies of this part
  • two #8 pan-head screws, 2 inches long, stainless steel
  • two #8 nuts, stainless
  • a white plastic card to hold the sticks. About 1.5mm thick, strong enough to support the weight and thick enough to fit securely in the card holder of the boat. The one I have pictured has not been cut down to size yet. The spacing of this unit should fit with your existing cards.
    • Locking is accomplished by a slightly tight fit with this piece - you will need a screwdriver to assemble this. Please note that the Life Gear lights turn off automatically after approximately one hour.
    Do not use this light in a situation (such as > 30 minutes before dawn) where this shutoff would be a problem because it would be extremely hard to reach the light to turn it back on. The "right-side-up" version prints with a clean portion that contacts the lights, but a messier portion near the screw holes. The overhang isn't correctly printed with my version of slic3r, but it's in a non-critical area. Pull out the extra plastic with pliers. The "upside-down" version prints with a clean screw hole, but is messier near the area that contacts the flashlights. It may also be more prone to popping off the bed. Both version will work; try them both! (you've got to print 4 anyway) Links to the glow stick on Amazon ($5-6 each, free shipping if order > $25). I found this at my local hardware store for $5.
    http://www.amazon.com/Life-Gear-Glow-Stick-Flashlight/dp/B0044Z3Y78/
    http://www.amazon.com/Life-Gear-Stick-Flashlight-Green/dp/B004D2WZ5E/
    http://www.amazon.com/Glow-GLOWSTICK-GRN-FLASHLITE-PPWGLOWSTICKG/dp/B001G27C98/
    They make a "waterproof" version of this product, and it looks like it would fit, but I have not verified this. The normal ones that I use come with an o-ring to seal them and look like they could take an occasional splash. -- This light has not been designed to meet any safety or navigation standard and the appropriateness for any application must be decided by the user. If this light does not provide adequate visibility, you must discontinue usage. THERE ARE NO OTHER WARRANTIES EITHER EXPRESS OR IMPLIED PROVIDED ON THIS PRODUCT. ALL OTHER WARRANTIES, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, INCLUDING IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF FITNESS AND MERCHANTABILITY, ARE EXPRESSLY EXCLUDED. WE FURTHER DISCLAIM ANY LIABILITY FOR ECONOMIC LOSS ARISING FROM CLAIMS OF PRODUCT FAILURE, NEGLIGENCE, DEFECTIVE DESIGN, MANUFACTURING DEFECT, FAILURE TO WARN AND/OR INSTRUCT, LACK OF SEAWORTHINESS, AND ANY OTHER THEORY OF LIABILITY NOT EXPRESSLY COVERED. TO THE EXTENT ALLOWED BY LAW, WE SHALL NOT HAVE ANY RESPONSIBILITY FOR LOSS OF USE OF THE PRODUCT OR THE BOAT, LOSS OF TIME, INCONVENIENCE, COMMERCIAL LOSS OR INCIDENTAL AND CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES.

description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43783 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=43783

Using the following options:
height = 4

If you have ever been stung by a jellyfish or coral you've already encountered one of these - a nematocyst. It is the stinging capsule found within specialized cells of Cnidaria (http://eol.org/pages/1745/overview). Nematocysts have poison filled harpoons that rapidly fire to attach to and incapacitate prey, or to deter predators. This model, an homage to the anatomical relief models that adorn doctors' offices and junior high science classrooms, shows the nematocyst in three stages of discharge. First, the inverted harpoon is packed within the capsule. The harpoon is inside-out at this point. Second, a stimulus has led the capsule to pressurize, swinging open the operculum (the trap door at the top), and begin everting the poison filled thread. As it extends, it turns right-sideout, exposing hooked barbs as it goes. Third, the thread is fully extended. At this point, it would be lodged in the flesh of whatever brushed up against it. This model was designed by Daniel Newman (http://www.danieljoelnewman.com), a certificate student in the Natural Science Illustration program at the Rhode Island School of Design, while doing an internship (facilitated by Amy Bartlet Wright, http://www.AmyBartlettWright.com) in my lab (http://dunnlab.org). His original concept sketches can be viewed above. Visit http://creaturecast.org for more stories about the unexpected world of Biology. Thanks to Stefan Siebert and Bryn Bliska.
We printed our models on a Makerbot Thing-O-Matic. You can go raftless, but we had better results with a raft.

remixed_from.author: DiabaseEngineer
remixed_from.title: Replicator Extruder for FLEXIBLE materials - Mk8

title: LeapFrog Creatr Extruder Modifications for NinjaFlex Rubber Filament

description.text:
Most extruders won't print flexible filaments like NinjaFlex and you need to modify the drive mechanism before you can print. The creatr's extruder is basically a modified MK8 extruder, but most of the spring loaded extruders on thingiverse won't fit a Creatr or they don't properly contain flexible filament. I worked with engineers from NinjaFlex to modify my Creatr with a spring loaded extruder drive mechanism and it works awesome.
Printer settings:
Speed: 30 mm/s
Temperature: 220C See instructions tab for details
Enjoy! 8/9/2014 - added step file for the whole assembly per user request

Print the following parts if you have a single extruder:
1) Pin
2) Arm
3) Base Plate
Print the following parts if you have a dual extruder
1) Pin (2)
2) Arm
3) Base Plate
4) Mirrored Arm
5) Mirrored Base Plate
Remove the front plate and fans from your extruder assembly. Then remove your Motor with the two screws located on the cold end bar at the bottom of the motor. Also removed the fixed bearing plate and spacer plate behind it. Remove the drive gear pulley and replace with a 1.75mm filament pulley (see below where to order). The drive pulley that comes with the creatr is designed for 3mm and won't squeeze the filament enough to properly drive it into the extruder.
You need to file/sand/drill the printed parts to make sure they fit and slide together. My prints required the hole on the base plate to be drilled out so the pin could spin freely. Be careful to not drill all the way through the parts. I also had to file down the cut out for the drive gear pulley so it could spin without dragging on pulley. Make sure you don't remove the bump that is located in the center of the pulley hobbled area. This is critical for keeping the filament from being sucked into the plastic part and jamming the extruder. The arm needs to be tapped with an M4 thread to accept the bearing screw. I also had to drill out the Arm to make clearance for the bearing screw head. Try to make this hole tight around the screw head.
Reassembly the extruder with the new printed parts. The spacer plate and fixed bearing plate are not needed, but you need to remove the bearing, washers, and screw to install them on the arm. Remember to replace the drive gear pulley with a new one for 1.75mm filament.
You need to buy the following parts:
1) Spring: McMaster Carr 9657K306
http://www.mcmaster.com/#9657k306/=ru23qy
2) 1.75mm drive gear pulley: Ultibots
http://www.ultibots.com/micro-extruder-drive-gear-1-75mm-filament/
I also recommend checking out Ninjaflex's site for tips on printing:
http://www.fennerdrives.com/default.aspx?node=ninjaflexfaq&

comments.text: ChelnodapV,  What type of filament are you using when it gets stuck in the extruder barrel?  If its ABS or another stiff plastic you can push it by hand into the extruder and it should extrude some plastic.  If you are using rubber this won't work. This will tell you if your tip is clogged or if the drive pulley system isn't gripping the filament correctly.

comments.text: Hi there. Great design! I just got a Creatr XL, and I'm looking to modify as much as possible. Is it really necessary to buy the replacement drive gear? Is there any reason the original wouldn't work well?
comments.author: Memnarch1113

comments.text: For rubber filament like Ninja Flex I couldn't get it to work until I swapped the drive gear.  The original drive gear would slip and couldn't grip the flexible filament correctly.  I think some people that have made this extruder modification have successfully used the original drive gear.  If you aren't planning to use flexible rubber filament then you don't need the special drive gear.
comments.author: Memnarch1113

comments.text: Sweet, thanks! I'll be getting the parts for this, and I'll post when I've finished the upgrade. Thanks for the great design!
comments.author: eliscott02

comments.text: Hello. I have printed and mounted the extruder modifications, and have used a spring like this: OD: 10mm, Overall length: 25.5mm, wire diameter: 1mm. compressed length: 9mm. The spring constant is close to 140 - 150 g/mm. It mounted very well. I want, however, to use it for regular ABS and PLA (purchased from Leapfrog, Maxx filaments). I am having problems printing with ABS. The filament makes it through, can even print for some time, but at some point it stops feeding. I have noticed the drive gear stops griping the filament and it shuffles off the filament, making it thinner in the place between the drive gear and the pulley, making it impossible to move downwards and upwards. I am using the original drive gear.
comments.author: Memnarch1113

comments.text: I think I see the problem here. With mine, I made it out of PLA for rigidity without taking into account the temperature of the extruder motor or the plastic transition temp of the PLA. I had the same problem, and decided to remove the spring and make an adjusting screw, since I thought the spring was collapsing (well, it was, but not THAT bad). It worked for a while, and I had to keep tightening up the adjusting screw about an hour into the print. Finally, I replaced the new parts with the old ones and lo and behold all the problems went away. I disassembled the new feed mechanism, and much to my astonishment saw that the screw holes for the movable arm were MELTED. I used steel screws for mounting it, and they conducted the heat from the motor right into the PLA. So if you actually make this thing, use a material that has a high plastic transition point. However, with that being said, the extruder motor for the Leapfrog Creatr has a 100 degree C temp rise rating, and it was running 60 degrees hotter-enough to poach an egg on. With that in mind, the only plastic I can think of with that high a temp rating is polycarbonate, and if you can't print with that, perhaps getting some metal parts printed would be a better idea. I have shelved the assembly for now. BTW: If you enclose the working space of the Creatr, it will MELT EVEN FASTER. One other point: I talked with a tech at Leapfrog, and they tell me that if the motors get too hot they will miss steps. Watch for that if you enclose the space.
comments.author: aleksandar_goaleng

comments.text: When the gear strips out the filament it can be caused from several things.  This happens because there is some type of restriction in pushing or pulling the filament into the extruder.
comments.author: aleksandar_goaleng

comments.text:
I will put some more photos up tomorrow. I used one of these from an MK9. http://cjr.en.alibaba.com/product/1780480723-0/MK9_Drive_gear_use_for_3d_printer_hot_sell_wanhao_high_quality.htmlhttp://cjr.en.alibaba.com/prod...
I also replaced the hot end with an alu hotend. It has a long ss throat with 4mm od liner. I drilled out the printer breach 9mm and fitted a ss nutsert in there and clamped it with grubscrew. I have the flange of the nutsert down and push it up from the bottom. The 4mm OD liner goes through the bottom of this extruder and right up to the gear. I used JB weld to glue the Alu hotend throat in the nutsert. It works really good no need for heat sink. I haven't had any problems. I also replaced the heatsink on the front with a MK9 which keeps it really cool. I can print 1.75mm filaflex which is really soft but a super strong and flexiable filament. 50mm/s max though. Hope this helps.
Nutsert
http://www.alibaba.com/product-detail/304-stainless-steel-flat-head-large_938820826.htmlhttp://www.alibaba.com/product...

description.text: I had some problems printing the Iris Door Box work with those tiny potrusions of plastic acting as guides (they just kept breaking), so I made a derivative with holes and M3 screws and bolts that uses the bottom of the hole as the guide. Only the box is modified, not the leaves nor the ring. Indeed the box looks just the same from the outside (except the bottom that has extra holes and extra screws :p) Thank you, countspatula, for making such an awesome yet simple box, I've always wanted to have one! All the credit to countspatula!

You will need the 3 STL objects in this thing (I only made the modified version of the small short iris door box) and 5 conical head 10mm M3 screws (or some like those, I used some old computer screws), and 5 M3 20mm screws with 5 M3 nuts that should be put inside the holes.
If the M3 nuts do not fit by pressing, use a soldering iron to press them, but be sure not to touch them afterwards, I've been burnt to many times by doing that (I'm reckless lol).

comments.text: Had to print @ 104% to make the 10mm m3 to fit, and ended up using some even smaller screws for the 20mm... but it works!

description.text: The design files for this thing have been removed as a protest against Stratasys after their decision to file a patent infringement lawsuit against Microboards Technology. Their decision is extremely destructive and also underlines that the patent system is obsolete as it no longer serves any purpose for the betterment of society. Its main role is as a blunt weapon used by incumbents to hamper innovation. I see absolutely no reason to continue indirectly supporting Stratasys by providing free content to Thingiverse.
After printing with ABS for a year, I decided to give PLA a try. The extruder nozzle clogged on almost every print, so I decided to attempt to add some additional cooling.

Remove the thin support material on part 2 and mount a ball bearing with an inner diameter of 4mm. You may have to cut the screw that holds the bearing in place to avoid making contact with the stepper motor or heat sink.
Spring dimension is probably not critical. The spring I used is 8 mm in diameter and 35 mm long. The fan is a standard PC power supply fan.

comments.text: I love it! I've been tinkering with something similar after seeing the replicator 2's extruder at maker faire, and NYCC.

comments.text: Thanks, but there are no guarantees :) I made it through a 6,5 hour print without any clogging yesterday, so I it looks promising so far.

comments.text: What temp did you find worked best for you?  I've finally got around to printing the fan hood and finding a fan that works, but I find I get a lot of jams.
comments.author: hansj66

comments.text: I experimented with temperatures in the 190 degree ballpark (HBP at 50). The higher the extrusion temperature, the harder it will be to prevent heat propagating back up into the extruder. With the fan active, I managed to print a 15 x 20 x 18 cm big Xenobird (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15047)http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... without any problems, but I still always had to pull out the filament, cut it and then reinserted it before each print to avoid it clogging. In my case, clogging will always happen if I start a new print with PLA that has melted and then been reheated in the nozzle.

title: Finder scope adaptor for Celestron 5SE
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I have a Celestron 5SE telescope, which has a StarSense accessory fitted. This meant that there was no room to fit a finder scope to the telescope. I don't really like the red dot finder that came with the scope, but have a 9 x 50 right angled finder scope spare.   
Its quite a nice fit and sits under the StarSense mounting shoe.  
It will also work if you want to add a different finder scope to the original red dot finder, but I cannot guarantee it will be rigid enough.  
I have added an STL to adapt the Celestron Red dot finder to fit my finder scope adaptor and any Skywatcher finder scope shoe.

I printed it at .2mm layer height, with 10% infill.  
You will need a 3mm dia bolt and nut. This is to tighten the finder scope to the holder, a bit like the real accessory shoe. You could glue the nut into the hexagonal recess inside the shoe to stop it coming out if you want.

This is a replacement forest tile for use in the game Memoir '44. Two versions are included, for variety. The design is inspired by JAWong's 3D Catan pieces (but designed from scratch).  
I've included the OpenSCAD for this as well. It's a mess, honestly, as I was learning how to use randomization and place elements in a reasonable way. Perhaps others will learn from it.
Apologies for not including an image of a completed product. Soon!

author: rbross

title: Printrbot LC Single Universal Extruder Mount

description.text:
Designed an extruder mount for the new Universal Extruder from this kickstarter project http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/qu-bd/open-source-universal-3d-printer-extruder-dual-ext There are some issues with this mount. One is that the fan is very close to the wall which may affect the cooling of the heatsink. If I were to extend even further, I may strain the Z axis rod due to torque. I am not sure if this will work with the double extruder version since the mount is different. Designed in Solidworks 2009 Update
5/26/2013
Uploaded ver2. This version requires the QU-BD MBE extruder to be oriented parallel to the mounting plate versus the original perpendicular mount. You can view my blog as a reference to see how it's mounted. You will need to cut slots into the mounting plate since none of the mounting holes are 50mm apart like the Wade Extruder. Update
7/19/2013
Finally got my QU-BD installed on the PB+, posted some pictures. Going to make a blog post on how to install the QU-BD parallel to the universal mount. Extruder lever mod by mickb
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43411

• Print and clean part if necessary.
  • Remove the 4 screws that's on the X carriage
  • Mount and install QU-BD extruder.
    • Pictorial guide in my build log
    http://gyroe3dprinter.blogspot.com/2013/07/build-log-34-custom-qu-bd-mount.html

comments.text: it's only for printrbot LC or i can use in my printrbot with ABS pieces?

description.text:
20 spaceships print out at once.  This will get you an armada quickly.  They make great little toys for kids. 
My kids use them as replacement pieces in board games, as well as making fun "space armada battles" with some imagination.  
"Pew-pew-pew" sounds sold separately (make your own).

The STL file will print 20 of these, in 3 rows, to fill the build space of a MakerBot Replicator. The last row is a set of slightly smaller ships. If you wish to get the blender (source) file, I'd be glad to share. Just contact me at [email protected]

author: Juan_cabrera23

description.text: Just in time to show off your manly pectorals, comes the Khan Necklace. No need to search 'round the moons of Nibia and 'round the Antares Maelstrom and 'round Perdition's flames any longer! Unleash your wrath by wearing it, and make all your nerdy friends jealous. Then print them their own since you're actually super nice.

• Print. This print includes the iconic broken Starfleet delta and a funny starburst pendant that I only noticed on Khan's necklace recently. I like to imagine Khan's wife gave it to him; he kind of hated it, but now that she's dead he wears it in her memory. If you want you can print just the delta.
  • OPTIONAL: Paint delta a dark brown with hints of aged bronze.
  • Thread 1.4mm diameter elastic cord or other equally thin string or wire through holes. Dangle broken Starfleet delta from starburst pendant.
  • Make into an awesome necklace. The starburst goes on the necklace in the center while the delta hangs below as pictured.
  • Look for worms to put in people's ears.
    • Want a cool phone dongle? Print the delta only version at 50% scale and tie a string to it! Pure awesome.

remixed_from.author: IvanFjodorovich
remixed_from.title: 40mm fan air duct for Geeetech All Metal J-head hotend

title: J-Head fan mount for Kossel Clear

description.text:
I wanted to use qwarex's air duct design (see "remixed from") to cool my hotend, but his mounts wouldn't work on the Kossel Clear effector plate, so I designed one using his mounting system that would. Any questions of comments? Leave them in the comments section or send me a message over at my thigiverse profile!
(and sorry for potato quality pictures)

You may have to use a 1/8th inch drill bit (or 3mm drill bit) to open the mounting hole up for an M3 screw.  
Since I didn't have any longer M3 bolts I cut one of the mounting bars off of the fan duct and only used one of them, it works perfectly with and M3-16 bolt. (See pictures)
